author: R Vimal Kumar
text:
The wives of some knitwear entrepreneurs in Tirupur decided that they would take an initiative to clean up their city instead of solely depending on officials to do so.

The piled up garbage at the Tirupur knitwear cluster has considerably dented the city’s image.

The women’s collective is now into segregation and disposal of wet and dry wastes generated both in their households and on the textile units/ commercial establishment premises.

Named SWAN (Sripuram Women's Active Network), the movement now has 100 women, mostly wives of industrialists.

“Our aim is to widen the base and rope in every household of industrialists in Tirupur cluster into this effort. We will go further out in the second phase of our drive,” said, Saradha Devi, coordinator of SWAN.

Explaining the project, Mrs. Devi said that while the women would use the wet wastes for composting, the dry wastes would be taken away for disposal by a company that SWAN has tied up with.

The SWAN as a consortium collectively procures ‘decomposing bags,’ needed to convert wet wastes into manure. Three such bags will be distributed to each household.

“The manure produced from the wet wastes will be used by the member women for their garden and farms. If we can’t use all of it, SWAN will sell the same to farm owners and generate revenue that will fund the operational costs of the Movement,” explained Mrs. Devi.
title: Women’s collective shows the way
